medical_history.chief_complaint: Abdominal pain, nausea, and elevated level of serum creatinine.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Symptoms began 4 months prior to admission with abdominal pain leading to a hospitalization for 10 days. Diagnosis of acute pancreatitis and gastritis was made at that time. Symptoms diminished minimally after treatment. Over the next 2 months, the patient had repeated evaluations and emergency visits for abdominal pain. Approximately 1 month before the current admission, the patient noted red blood in stools and experienced intermittent abdominal and rectal pain. Two weeks before admission, normal abdominal and rectal exams were conducted, revealing occult blood in stool. One week prior, epigastric pain similar to prior episodes was reported, accompanied by other reflux symptoms, followed by anorexia, nausea, and occasional vomiting. Four days before admission, colonoscopy revealed nonbleeding, small hemorrhoids and normal findings otherwise. Symptoms progressed with worsening abdominal pain, leading the patient to seek emergency care.
medical_history.past_medical_history: History of gastroesophageal reflux disease, hypertension, benign prostatic hypertrophy, cluster headaches, chronic back pain with degenerative joint disease, and colonic polyps seen on endoscopy 3 years earlier. Past surgeries include soft palate resection for carcinoma, excision of a neck lipoma, hydrocele repair, and left knee arthroscopy.
medical_history.family_history: Mother had heart disease and died at age 80; father died in a motor vehicle accident; sister has hypertension; all six children are healthy.
medical_history.social_history: Former machinist, stopped working due to back pain. Born in the southeastern United States, divorced, in a monogamous heterosexual relationship. No history of sexually transmitted diseases. 20-pack-year history of smoking, stopped 15 years ago; heavy alcohol user, stopped 7 months ago; does not use illicit drugs.
